{"nick":"zsoc","message":"joepie91: there's a ride in disney fl called 'Mission: Space' which uses a really neat mechanic to simulate g-forces. There's 4 people in a pod and a few pods in each room and rooms are surrounded by a circular elevating system, it's really disorienting. It's hard to tell what is moving or where. But anyway, the g-forces are applied by centrifugal motion. But it's so sensory encapsulated that it's impossible to tell you're spinning in a circle. {"nick":"ecmabot","message":"zsoc: Promises are placeholders for values that'll be provided in the future. They allow composing asynchronous operations like synchronous ones. See http://robotlolita.me/2015/11/15/how-do-promises-work.html and https://blog.domenic.me/youre-missing-the-point-of-promises/. Contrast with !cps & see https://bevacqua.github.io/promisees/","date":"2017-05-11T20:53:18.350Z","type":"message"}

{"nick":"pstef_","message":"This is not a counter-argument, it's more like a confession, but personally, I'm hesitant about using promises. I understand the value they provide, but two main implementations have what I consider major flaws. Native ES6 promises are not recommended for various reasons and bluebird (usually recommended) is not a core feature and I tend to avoid those whenever I can.","date":"2017-05-11T20:59:30.853Z","type":"message"}
